results.title: Scott no friends
results.brief_description:
This responsive display presents the moment, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

PM Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. His 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised at home and abroad for lacking any real details, except faith that uninvented tech might save the day, and the French president labelled him a liar over the submarine fiasco. Other world leaders made their displeasure to the government’s handling of recent issues known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. Not only did the French president label him a liar over the submarine fiasco, his 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised around the world (and at home) for lacking any new funding, policies or details – except faith that yet-to-be-invented tech might save the day. Other world leaders made their displeasure known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo opportunity.

While the original footage in this video was broadcast on 7 News, Labor MP Patrick Gorman (and likely his social media team) added the theme music to TV show Curb Your Enthusiasm, equating the Australian Prime Minister with the fictional version of Larry David, whose ignorance and disregard for social conventions results in awkward, cringe-worthy moments on the show. The addition of end cards further establishes the sitcom style, featuring the names of other coalition members, suggesting that the government’s climate policy is a joke that’s resulted in this bumbling Larry David-like instance of international embarrassment.
description_for_label: PM Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. Not only did the French president label him a liar over the submarine fiasco, his 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised around the world (and at home) for lacking any new funding, policies or details, except faith that uninvented tech might save the day. Other world leaders made their displeasure known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo opportunity.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Blood
results.brief_description:
Travelling through Australia with his film camera, Ivan Sen has visited many Aboriginal communities, from urban to prison to distant-rural. Photographing people in their definitive environments, he has created an installation which is a subtle and deeply moving meditation on skin, landscape, gesture and the many nuances of Aboriginal identities.

The work contains imagery of people who have all shared the same blood. The blood of the Gamilaroi people of Northern NSW.

results.title: Beef Carcase Competition
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this film contains footage of dead animals.

This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was made to promote and highlight the pristine quality beef produced in the Western district of Victoria and Eastern South Australia.

It documents the annual contest to select the best beef carcase; in this instance, held in Portland, Victoria.

results.title: Where the River Kiewa Flows
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was created to promote the ingenuity of the Kiewa Valley diary industry, which supplied milk and butter to the people of Melbourne and Sydney.

The film highlights one farm’s introduction of a piggery to make use of their surplus milk and generate a secondary revenue stream.

results.title: Farm Newsreel No. 1
results.brief_description: This newsreel film features agricultural activities throughout Victoria, Australia. Activities featured include hop harvesting in Myrtleford, tobacco harvesting in Ovens Valley, onion harvesting in Colac, and silage distibution in Upper Pakenham.

results.title: The Mallee Research Station
results.creator_credit: Colin Webb and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was created to promote the ingenuity of agricultural scientists working at the Mallee Research Station in Walpeup, Victoria.

The film highlights the research station’s development of wheat production, sheep breeding and pasture improvements. It contains some wonderful examples of farm machinery and farming techniques of the era.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents a glimpse of a somewhat nostalgic version of Australian suburban family life as it was in the 50s and early 60s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 children playing with sprinkler and toys 1950s
00:02:19:00 leaving hospital with baby
00:03:39:00 a 1950s Christmas scene; children with toys
00:04:59:00 brief shot of Queenscliff with kids riding in Cobb & Co. horse-drawn carriage
00:06:53:00 girl jumping on a trampoline with pier in the background – trampoline park with interesting “trampolines” sign
00:08:59:00 nice shot of toddler waddling towards the camera
00:12:54:00 backyard children’s birthday party
00:17:05:00 young girl using a hula hoop in a paddock
00:18:02:00 toddler gets a home haircut

results.title: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.credit_line:
Jason Phu
Three-channel video installation, 85 mins.
Edited by Conor Bateman
Mordant Family Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like “Drunken Master” (1978) and “Avatar the Last Airbender” (2005–08), “Analects of Kung Phu” presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s “Dao De Jing”, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales. Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.
results.title_for_label: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow
results.description:
“I want to create something that is genuinely useful but is also aware of its own representational fallacies and historical inaccuracies. I hope that people notice the highly personal nature of this work and feel inspired to make their own compendium of sayings to guide their own lives.” – Jason Phu

During times of uncertainty, people look for guidance. Jason Phu found it in martial arts films. By reclaiming wise sayings from movies and TV shows like Drunken Master (1978) and Avatar the Last Airbender (2005–08), Analects of Kung Phu presents a moving image philosophy for surviving contemporary life. Taught by action stars but inspired by classic Chinese texts like Lao Zi’s Dao De Jing, he questions whether these life lessons are genuinely useful. Phu is aware of how wisdom can be oversimplified and misused, how film subtitles miss the mark or even present a completely different narrative, and how we are guided in our day-to-day life by the movies we watch.

Leading Melbourne-based visual artist Jason Phu’s multi-disciplinary practice includes printmaking, installation, painting and video. Born in 1989 in Sydney, Australia, Phu lives and works in Melbourne, Australia. Phu’s artworks often explore Chinese histories in Australia, his own family history, and Chinese/Vietnamese folktales.

Jason Phu is the 2021 recipient of the Mordant Family Moving Image Commission for young Australian artists.

results.title: Yanmeeyarr
results.credit_line:
Vicki Couzens

Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens

Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel

Commissioned by ACMI and co-created with Jeph Neale and Hilary Jackman
results.material_description:
Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens.
Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel.
results.brief_description: In Yanmeeyarr, Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_primary.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Light and shadow have been a powerful storytelling tool long before they were the basis for the moving image. For thousands of generations in Australia, First Peoples storytelling has harnessed the movement of the world and play of light: the special glow of sunset to catch the movement of dancing feet, the flickering campfire as tales are told in the night, the story of stars and constellations told in the Dreaming.

In this multi-part artwork Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

“Where does moving image originate? Shadow and light, elemental movement and action; see figures in formation, ceremony in the circle, moving, in rhythm, in rhyme with the heartbeat, sunlight, moon shadow, Yanmeeyarr… flickering in firelight. Dancers painted and adorned, in corroboree, in ceremony, telling story through the dance. The viewer in movement and reflection becomes part of the dance, as the figures become animated. Yanmeeyarr, flickering in the firelight, is reflected in the present; the viewer and the new technologies of today, become part of the work and the ongoing past-present-future of our storytelling continuum.” – Vicki Couzens

Yanmeeyarr is generously supported by the Sidney Myer Fund
